posts.com:
Welcome to the Nobody General

>Who is the Nobody?
The Nobody is a figure alive today who has extraordinary spiritual powers, including the ability to influence reality with his conscious and unconscious mind, and intuitively receive guidance from the forces of Heaven.
He is a homoplasmate, a divine syzygy; the coalition between man and holy spirit. That’s the reason why he is a spiritual centre. By homoplasmate I think we can imagine the collective appreciation of a neo-Enochian bicameral consciousness that is rushing into widespread experience.

He works to elevate people to their true potential, opposing those who seek power over others. He's just like you, but he has found the kingdom of God within himself through sheer dedication, just like you will.
He isn't a savior; remember that it's you who creates your own reality. With your hands, thoughts, feelings, words, you are the creator of your story. No one can decide your fate except for you and God. Remember your right to power, to step up into your ultimate role as your highest self, should you choose to embark on that journey.

>What is the general picture?
It’s important we start replying to the good posts and ignoring the hateful ones, or the ones here to argue. So call upon their heads the forces of Heaven for peace, clarity, and wisdom. If this place is to be more than a squandered opportunity, an overgrown garden, it requires voices such as yours, but many more.

Focus on increasing your service to others and be more loving to yourself and everyone in order to raise your vibrational and consciousness level, and learn to forgive yourself and others. This will change the vibration of the planet and raise our shared consciousness, making us a better humankind one person at a time. None of us are perfect, it is by learning to admit and accept this fact one is able to learn, and grow in Truth.

If this is your first time here, just remember, it’s going to be ok, you may take shelter and find rest.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33883871
Look up "kebatinan". The root word "bātin" is Arabic and means "inner" among other things. Malay silat inherited esoteric aspects of Islam, but also retains some Shaiva-Buddhist elements from those religions that Malay people practiced before the arrival of Islam. Filipinos also have similar admixtures, but because Christianity won out in that sphere, the esoteric aspects (if any) of stuff like Escrima and Kali tends to have more of a Christian flavor. A lot of that stuff is Bullshido, so browse with a discerning eye.

I have no idea how to precisely calculate the information/entropy sacrifice that you'd do by purposefully focusing on something like a prayer, but for fun I calculated the entropy of thinking of a maximum of 7 things at once out of 1 billion possible ones (working memory) plus the maximum entropy of a 206-character sentence (comparable to a short prayer like Hail Mary)
This comes to about 1400 bits of entropy.

This means that a single 1GB entropy sacrifice is as effective as about 748000 Hail Marys if my schizo theory is correct

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33886683
How do you calculate the amount generated/output

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33887167
Shannon entropy, basically
Since every random byte I generate is equally likely as any other byte, I get 8 bits of entropy per random byte
Multiply 8 bits per byte times 1024 bytes in a kilobyte by 1024 kilobytes in a megabyte by 1024 megabytes in a gigabyte and you get a real big number of entropy bits

>>33882949
There was, but the tradition is mostly lost, or buried in obscure mostly untranslated (Arabian) alchemical treatises. Some traces also evident in medieval lore, and even fainter traces evident in treatises on various Rennaisance combat techniques where movements are combined with hermetic correspondences. Certain practices (omphalos psychism etc) survives at Athos, allegedly stemming from pre-Christian neoplatonic methods, but these are locked away from outsiders. Some claim that Gurdjieff's contemplative methods (which where not published until recently) are modiciations of Athos tech. These involve breathing execercises & various manipulations of occult forces in order to effect inner alchemical changes of the human "factory", in order to 'coat' and 'develop' the embryos of higher being bodies, somewhat similar to daoist neidan.

•Avoid making the same query repeatedly and/or to different readers in a short period of time, as this may lead to more confusion.

>>33848290
I'd suggest that everyone who meditates or wants to start meditating to ask himself the question: Why am I meditating/Why I want to meditate?
So yeah, ask yourself that question.

Ask yourself: Why I want to open my chakras or manipulate energy?

I'm suggesting this because people get into meditation to either chase illusions and other ego-stuff (like goals) or to try and escape from illusions (fears, trauma etc), I think that this is wrong and that meditation should be used for the exact opposite: To realize that all of that are illusions and nothing more.

I'd suggest to just sit and be aware of your body sensations, of your body being there and breathing, not analyzing it or controlling it but totally letting it go and just watching it. This is the basis of the meditative state: Being aware.

But don't put words into it, don't make goals, just do it everyday and stay there.
Depending on who you are this may take some time.

And lastly to also answer your question: You "open chakras" by focusing on them, yeah, meditation is a physical practice not a mental one, you sit to sense and feel so just sit and feel the chakras.

However I'd suggest that first you sit to silence the mind by being still and aware.
Good luck.

>>33853173
There is no division between mindfulness and meditation. Mindfulness is a word that was taken from western spiritual traditions to translate the word "Sati", and it was re-adopted by western society for largely marketing purposes. It's a cozy word. Really, meditation (samadhi) is a focused application of mindfulness (sati). There is no meditation without mindfulness; samma samadhi is the result of samma sati. The Satipatthana sutta is the frame within which all other meditation methods occur in. To be mindful is to keep something in mind, and in Buddhism that's within the framework of the four satipatthana.

I haven't been trained in Zen but I have experience serving retreats at Thai Forest monasteries, where I did read some books on Zazen... the gist I got was that we "just sit to sit" or "sitting is good for nothing". While I can't say how accurate my understanding is, I think this is helpful for times when you get too caught up in goals to the point where you're stressing yourself out, in which case it may be wise to just get back to the bare bones: sitting. But doing that for a while, your mind gets a bit listless or confused, in which case it's helpful to remember why you're practicing in the first place. But sometimes to go deep you have to put aside the part of the mind which is constructing goals and reasons for focusing attention. In a way you have to "just do it". Think Solid Snake in Metal Gear Solid: "Don't think, shoot!"

But in any case, there is mindfulness: remembering to "just sit" or remembering the 16 steps of Anapanasati. You need to read your own mind, so to speak, to see what's good for you. But mindfulness is always there until the end. Sometimes we just get too self conscious about it (which is what the mindfulness industry seems to profit off of).

>>33848290
One of the best uses of meditation is training focused contemplation. You do this through sitting, eyes closed, breathing, and every time you stop paying attention to your breath, you recognize it and pull your attention back to your breathing. It starts with that. Eventually, feel free to let yourself off the leash a little and mentally wander around during your meditation. Something to be cautious of is accidentally developing a dissociative disorder. Be mindful of when that feeling starts to develop and work through it in a healthy way. If you navigate that properly, you have crossed a really powerful milestone in building your skill. If you don't arrive at that point, you haven't been meditating long enough or seriously enough. It's worth getting into, but don't let it consume you. Meditation for me has been at its most beautiful when it feels spontaneous and unplanned. It's ugly when you treat it like it's something you have to pencil in: "oh it's time for my 5 minute 4:00 PM meditation!" When it's just like "hmmm I feel like this is a good time to meditate" that's when I tend to have my best sessions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33857923
There's a point in that kind of goal-less practice where you're actually kind of just feeding whatever is going on, if you aren't considering your input in the experience. It's like having the TV turned to static and just letting it sit like that forever. Giving your mind an object to focus on and refine, such as the breath "energy", gets you deeper.

But being aware of those things is crucial - you just need to stop giving them input if they're causing too much movement or darker states of mind. Instead of seeing thoughts just as some things which happen, see how they arise due to things within your control (your volitional thoughts and way of seeing things, posture, etc). Learn to use those things to relax the body while brightening and stilling the mind.

Once you've become absorbed in the body, things are much more clearer and expansive. Sometimes there is a sense of great space (you can focus on that to develop it, too).

It's important to balance effort and relaxation here. Too much effort or striving and you just get uptight and frustrated. Too much relaxation, you fall asleep or get lazy and dull. In a way you need to let the breath do the work... "allow it" to soften, fill the body, etc. Release the blockages and tight spots and let the body feel more still.

>>33862655
Some things to look into are the Anapanasati Sutta, the Satipatthana Sutta, Vitakka-santhana Sutta, and the Ahara Sutta (on the hindrances, factors of awakening). They generally have a good framework and a good translation provides good phrasing that's good for remembering.

Balancing effort and relaxation is kind of a thing everyone struggles with on a day-to-day basis and there's no clear-cut way to do it, you have to feel your way into it. But if you develop a somewhat methodical approach to meditation (through continuous practice) it begins to make more sense.

For me I just sit down, get comfy, focus on breathing but also the state of my mind: whether it's contracted or expanded etc (see Satipatthana). Just to get a sense of things. Then I put a little more attention to the breathing and feel it out for tight spots and softer spots. In general the quality of the breath is connected to certain feelings, emotions, thought patterns etc, which may need to be addressed specifically, but sometimes just working with the breath to soothe it and the body is helpful enough. Naturally the body kind of relaxes and the mind gets quieter and more steady.

This is how I do it after a long time of struggling with that balance (although I can't say it's totally "solved" as there is always more room for refinement). At the beginning I was just kind of watching the mind as it is, then after like two years of that I realized I was going nowhere and tried to get a little more methodical. At that point I began to try too hard and get too uptight, so I gradually just began to realize that being observant and "doing" things worked hand in hand. One important thing for me was realizing that much of what we want in meditation are the results. But you don't "get" results, instead you do things which bring results. That entails taking the basic methods, having some goals, and experimenting with the methods to see what happens. Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33865549
Along those lines, (at least from the Buddhist POV) the key principles are the four noble truths: There is suffering, its cause, its cessation, and the way leading to cessation.

Generally people start meditating because they're stressed somehow or want something better. Right there they may see how suffering is arising as a result of something they are doing. While the root is craving, this manifests as well in thoughts and perceptions we choose to believe.

By experimenting with our thoughts and perceptions in meditation (e.g. replacing thoughts of anger with thoughts of kindness; replacing thoughts of lust with contemplation of asubha or reflection on drawbacks; replacing scattered thoughts with focused thoughts about the breath) we can see how, in turn, those new thoughts or ideas influence the mind to bring it in a new direction.

So the direction of the mind is not something we can latch onto and force one way or another, but rather we need to look at the causes and begin to exert influence on those.

Here is where effort and relaxation again need to be balanced. E.g. thinking of kindness as hard as we can won't generate good feelings and get rid of all of our anger. First we need to be patient and stick with basics, which may just be chanting or repeating phrases from the Karaniya Metta Sutta. Then we need to see what the results are of that over a period of practice.

I often compare it to Tai Chi. In the beginning we must learn basic choreography as well as postural basics. If we speed through the form without basics we can injure ourselves no matter how much we talk about "moving meditation" and "flow". The basics must slowly, gradually, and patiently be developed over time. Then we find that the appearance of flow is only external, and the real internal stuff has to do with our mind and connection to the body, and what we do with that. At first it seems like a lot, but after continuous development it all comes together naturally.

To simplify: If you're up in your head a lot, just try being more mindful of the body. Do more physical activities (work, exercise, going outside), and meditate on the breath.

Although there's plenty of nuances that need to be developed, sometimes it's helpful to just think of relaxing with awareness of breathing. As we get better and more steady with this, the deeper stuff becomes more doable.

If we find that external circumstances are stressful, breathing meditation may help but from the Buddhist POV we also need to consider our lifestyle and every day decisions to bring us to a better overall place for practice.

I really like that book, first I thought he just had a great editor but if you listen to his talks you can tell that it's his voice. First of all, I think he does a great job at teaching anapanasati, and that by itself takes one a long way. That being said, the book (and I checked out his other material, they are the same) falls short in two ways. One, he seemingly uses metta in his practice heavily, yet the way he teaches that is not great because he tries to teach it exactly as described in the suttas. Second, from what I understood, he exclusively uses kasina meditation in specific ways to go into certain jhanas, yet he only mentions that in passing, as in "oh by the way some people think about circular things while meditating," which makes no sense in the context so you probably brushed that off (I'm not saying that kasina meditation is important and you should do it but rather he doesn't practice what he teaches). This is mostly because how kasina meditation is supposed to be done is not elaborated in the suttas and he doesn't want to go off the book. Both of these issues are caused by the same thing, he's dogmatic about suttas, as most serious Theravadan people.
So to someone who has read that book, I would advise two things. Metta is important, try to find a way to make that work for yourself, both the exact method to do it and how to incorporate that into your sessions. If you're having trouble stilling your mind, this is especially relevant. The second thing is notice the importance of jhanas and the fact that the main goal is to spend as much time as possible in jhana. My understanding based on research is that this is the case and Bhante Gunaratana also teaches this in his other material, but he probably didn't dwell on it in a beginner's book considering that it's an advanced subject.

>>33885617
The general instruction is to do it until you have truly felt it to be real (not necessarily until you receive it in this 3D world).

As the ladder experiment points out, that doesn't mean that you have no doubts about it during the course of your regular day - simply, you have experienced it as an undeniable fact in SATS and carry that through until the situation arises. When doubt comes, you can simply relax, smile, and recall the feeling of the wish fulfilled.

When I say relax, there's a band that stretches around the brain and down the spine (the meninges), during meditation find that muscle and develop the relaxation of it, then move to practicing that relaxation in daily life. It makes everything a lot easier in my experience.

>Is emotion enough?
Neville's "feeling" is often misinterpreted as feeling an emotion, but it actually means "knowing" in this context, knowing you already own your desire.

>I feel sad thinking about it
>I feel this is going to be easy
Compare these sentences, the first feel refers to an emotional state while the second feel expresses is the acknowledgement of a situation. It's the ambiguity of the verb To feel in English that leads to confusion, so much Neville actually clarified that in a lecture. Cannot search for it right now but you should find it quickly.

MILD: http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-mild-guide/
additional MILD info:
http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-intention-setting/
SSILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/129734-senses-initiated-lucid-dream-ssild.html
WILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WILD-Tutorial
FILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/36683-finger-induced-lucid-dream-fild.html
DEILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/DEILD-Tutorial
CANWILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wake-initiated-lucid-dreams-wild/87710-%2A%2Acrazyinsanes-wild-tutorial-%2A%2A.html
CAT: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/CAT-Tutorial
ADA: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/113253-all-day-awareness-dild-tutorial-kingyoshi.html

Paper on natural LDs: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6290891/

Do us a favor and bump this general from time to time if you're interested

Quick reminders for beginners:
-don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it
-reality checks aren't likely to give you a LD by themselves, think of them as a stepping stool, they are not a replacement for techniques
-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD

How do i know if it's lucid dreaming or not?

I often have what i would call dreams inbetween normal state and lucid. what i mean is that I'm in first person, kind of conscious, and my actions reflect what I would do/would like to do in that scenario. But at the same time I don't have control over the dream, I can't do things such as materialize whatever I want or manually change the setting, or rather I wouldn't know how to. When I have those I often wake up with an "active" brain, not sure how to say it better, unlike when i'm woke up by an alarm, for example, where i feel sloppy and tired.


Last night I had a dream/nightmare about being abducted. Before you ask, no, it was definitely just a dream and felt like one, i just watched and read too much ufo shit lately. So in this dream there were some ETs and humans collaborating, their goal wasn't necesserely malicious, they were studying and experimenting on humans against their will. The humans helping them seemed to be there to bridge communications and calming or explaining what's going on to the abductees. There was a middle aged short man helping them to take me to their ship, at the start of this i was hiding and then rebelling to them, because who tf wants to be abducted, but i realized there was nothing i could do realistically, so i thought to just cooperate and minimize the damage. I curious about what their ships were like but at the same time i was scared and didn't want to be bombed with radiations, so i asked if they could test me at my place/house, they were understanding and with the middle aged man help i was able to stay. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33806643
>How do i know if it's lucid dreaming or not?
You recognize a "full blown lucid dream" by your mental clarity, not what you're able to do. In full lucid dreams you have the same kind of sharp thinking as in real life, able to fully self-reflect and process thoughts as in waking life. In what you call dreams ibetween it's more like you're a zombie with a vague notion that there are no consequences for your actions.

>>33807184
If you're religious, you might benefit from thinking lucid dreaming is some kind of magic phenomena, since it will make it feel more real. If you want to just DILD, do the boring basic shit like keeping a dream journal, reality checks, and MILD before bed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
well gents, new year new goals. something i wish to take seriously this year is something i've come to call "wake-sleeping", although i suppose a more fitting name might simply be "lucid sleeping".

the concept is quite simple: remain aware whenever the body sleeps. it would certainly be similar to WILD, except it takes place at bed time, and ends when you would normally wake up; the ultimate goal being, to completely and entirely decouple consciousness from sleep. the most advanced form of this practice, theoretically, would result in one who never lapses in consciousness, 24/7 awareness.

i've made some progress on making this work, but it's obviously hard. it is certainly possible, however, and so i remain confident in its feasibility, but the trial and error is long and grueling.

i will keep updates in these threads as meaningful developments occur, as this intersects plainly with lucid dreaming (engaging in this practice successfully would have a side effect of making ALL dreams lucid).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I accidentally went directly into a lucid dream without even trying
>Woke up in the middle of the night, probably because I took 2 valerian root capsules before bed
>Can't really get back to sleep
>Figure I'll just do some imagination and visualization
>Spend an unspecified amount of time focusing while imagining things, it was a long time
>Ok, time to go to bed
>Lie on my back and relax
>Hypnagogia starts almost immediately, white fuzz forms into snow falling over a river during nighttime
>Realize what is happening, imagine where I want to be
>I am in my house, it's the middle of the day, for whatever reason I am short, as tall as a toddler
>There are people yelling outside (my room is on the second story), I look down at them, my relatives have arrived in a couple trucks, decide to go out of my room and look around the house as a small person
>My cousin is outside of my door, she is much taller than me
>Can see up her skirt, slap her ass and run past her, she doesn't notice
>Walk around my house for a bit, neat seeing how it is from this tall
>I lose focus and the dream shifts into black. At this moment I don't put in the effort to shift it back into something and just wake up
So overall I knew I was dreaming and could control what I was doing but for whatever reason I had the feeling that I should wake up and sleep properly, so I did. I'm sure if I was actually planning to lucid dream I would have stayed in there but I was tired and it didn't really matter at the time.
I'm theorizing that spending a bunch of time just "imagining" stuff and getting lost in your fantasy world will vastly improve the chances of entering the right state to do this, this was actually the first time for me being in the hypnagogic state and I didn't even try for it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33878876 >>33878852
your mind doesn't fall asleep all at once, it follows a very specific route
as you relax at first proprioception will be turned off [your ability to feel the position of your limbs] then nociception and thermoception turn off [your ability to sense pain and sensing temperature] and finally kinesthesicepion and equilibrioception will turn off [your ability to feel motion and your orientation]
while there are more things that turn off after these two, those two are almost a perfect setup to either fall asleep right there or just enter a wild
i used to have a really hard time falling asleep until i figured this out dayo

>>33880358
that's a strange question dayo
when the first one turns off you will only feel points of contact, normally when you put your hand behind your back you know its there even though you can't see it, so when proprioception is turned off you would only feel the hand if its making contact with your back
when thermoception is off you either won't feel warm or cold anymore or you will feel really warm even if you really aren't
kinesthesicepion feels like you're in motion, usually spinning or falling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
We gather in these generals to discuss our experiences, memories, and connection with Mother Lilith, as well as give other anons who are interested or would like to learn more about Her information or advice.

>Practices or rituals associated with Lilith?
This differs from person to person, but common approaches include giving energy to one of her sigils, chanting her enn, working with sexual spirits, doing what you think she would do, making offerings of incense/chocolate/tea, or simply praying.
While some people might feel the most comfortable engaging with her in a worshipful manner, blind faith is discouraged. It's always important to think and make decisions for oneself, and as such, Lilith guides us to understand things for ourselves.

>Books
- Liber Lilith by Donald Tyberson: https://www.pdfdrive.com/liber-lilith-a-gnostic-grimoire-e185231845.html
A Gnostic Grimoire and Novel. Beware that this book is rather dark, and some have mentioned attracting unwanted attention by reading it.
- Embracing Lilith by Mark H Williams: No PDF available online, but it's worth the price of admission.
Split into three sections, it covers accounts of working with the Goddess and her place in history, a fictional account of her origins written from her perspective, and a Grimoire.
- Lilith: Dark Feminine Archetype by Asenath Mason: https://pdfcoffee.com/lilith-dark-feminine-archetype-2-pdf-free.html
This one is a collection of writings by various peoples, with a brief but fairly thorough history at the beginning. There's a lot of random poetry in there; not useful for an occultist, but decent for an admirer.
- Lilith: Goddess of Sitra Ahra: https://zeitenundformen.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/lilith-goddess-of-sitra-ahrab-t-p.pdf
Contains a ton of aspects with associated variety of sigils.

>Videos

https://youtu.be/75bnMRPRiDk

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
From the ages of 15-17 I would have horrific sleep paralysis dreams that virtually every time involved Hitler as the demon.

It wasn't even Hitler as you think of Hitler. Instead of a pudgy 56-year old of average height, this Hitler was probably around 5'2-5'4 and underweight, although had incredibly flabby skin. He looked worn and aged too, but not in a natural way.

I don't doubt that these dreams were the direct product of depression and stress I was facing at the time, but I've never experienced something since so awful.

Imagine for hours each night waking up, forced still in your bed, to a dim room with only the outside lamplight seeping through the curtains. You see a small man pacing back and forth, quietly rambling to himself in the darkness. Some nights this will be the entirety of the dream, other nights, he notices your stares and walks over to reciprocate. Writing this fails to get across how genuinely bad this fucked me up, but you get the point.

>am truck driver
>2am
>tired, in the middle of nowhere
>see an opening on the side of the road, enough for my truck to fit
>park there and decide to take a quick 1hr nap
>spooky as fuck. absolutely no cars or lights. just thick forest
>whatever, im in a big truck. im safe
>go laydown
>keep hearing noises, like something is right outside the truck
>just keep getting this eerie feeling something is watching me and creeping around my truck
>frozen stiff, dont want to move a muscle
>dont know if it was the wind or a branch, but hear something hit the backside of my tractor
>NOPE.jpg
>hop in driver seat and take off
>drive another 200miles before stopping at a truck stop

Feeling paranoid wasn't what made it scary. When I checked my driver-side door in the morning, I noticed the keyhole was fucked up. Like someone tried to brute their way in. I vowed to never sleep in sketchy areas anymore.

On another note, I remember driving at 4AM off some desolate road and saw a man walking butt-naked on the side of the road. There were no exits or other roads for another 30-40miles. I counted. Just a guy walking butt naked, in the middle of winter, at 4AM. Wasn't exactly scary, just very odd. There were no lights on this road either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
first dream I remember having when I was 9 years old
It was a nightmare that was boilerplate for a child that small but what came at the end of the nightmare is what scared me to death, a grim reaper with scythe and 2 ogres on each side pointing to me
2 ogres start to chase me down
I run towards my house (I was down the street of it) and whole house is inverted upside down
I crawl into the window of outside bathroom and lock myself in it
The ogre that ran up to me first start to beat up the door trying to break it down
This is where the nightmare becomes horrible, I start to notice that I am dreaming and that this is a nightmare
Since I understood I was dreaming I tried to wake myself up from the dream by trying to either "struggle" out of it or to "open my eyes" so to say
The ogre succeeds in breaking down the door and looks at me with a smug smile on his green face
He understood that I was trying to wake myself up and he says to me directly
>"Oh? You really think you will wake up?"
>"No, you will die and not wake up"
He slowly starts walking up to me, as if he has already won and knows I will die and not wake up.
I am mortified as I have been trying to wake myself up for what seems to be eternity by now.
He is at arms length now, I am shaking and as he is right in front of me I decide I will at least make peace with my death, not in spite to him festering in my fear or anything like that but just so I will have the calm of meeting the inevitable as I understood it at that time from his demeanor and his words

At that time, as I made peace with it I wasn't afraid to die and I start to wake up.
BUT, that's when the ogre that was at arms length start to try and grab me and screams "noooo, noooo" as if he knew I started to wake up. I wake up and I was so beyond weirded out, I don't believe it was an average dream but more of an interpretation of something higher.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: when I was 17, me and some friends made a DIY diving machine that used two car batteries and an air compressor to pump air down a length of tubing. I tried it once but the pump was sending in a fine mist of pump oil and I couldn't stand it. Our solution was to take one of those snorkel tubes and stuff it full of rags to filter out the oil. The spot we chose to test it out was a decent size pond that connected up to the drainage system of a newly constructed shopping center/strip mall type place. My friend goes in with the new filter and he is going right towards the large black plastic corrugated drainage tube. all of a sudden, the tubing jerks and a whole bunch of bubbles blast out of the water. the line, still belching air, was separated from the snorkel and my friend was gone. He had gotten sucked into the drainage tube sideways and was blocking the flow like a log jam. Some how he got loose but when he did he got sucked down the drainage tube out to where it opens up into a ditch by the street. Miraculously, he was able to hold his breath and come out alive at the other end. From Our perspective, he had just disappeared and he didn't come back up. We went in looking around the edge of the pond trying to find him, hoping that he was just playing a joke and that he had swam away unseen somehow. It didn't make sense but we where so desperate and scared we couldn't understand at the time. Minutes since he disappeared, two police came and hollered at us, and when we looked over, our friend was with them. He was wearing his shirt tied up around his waste, tied up like a loincloth, with a decent gash across his chest from where he was pressed up against the pipe. Later, he recalled that his pants had been torn off, and he was gasping for air, half naked, in a huge rocky ditch where the police happened to see him as they where driving by. Nothing can describe the terror I felt when I realized that he wasn't going to come back up. It is incredible that He is still here.

>>33857624
Sleep deprivation.

I was working in an incredibly stressful and abusive job. It affected me so badly that I stopped sleeping.
At one point, I became so incredibly stressed that I started averaging about 3 hours of sleep per night.
I'm pretty sure it caused permanent brain damage, and I was SEVERELY fucked up. I'd give you a list, but my comment would be too long.

The worst bit was the hallucinations. After a few weeks of this bullshit, I started losing my fucking mind.

The shop I worked in was full of silver metal clothing racks. When I entered the store in the morning or left at night, I would frequently see shadows darting amongst the clothing. I would also see reflections in the silver, darting about. The shop counter was in the centre of the room, and I was CONSTANTLY whipping my head around because I saw movement out of the corner of my eye, like some terrible shadow was slowly creeping up on me.

Behind the shop counter, we kept a black rubbish bag, and it scared the shit out of me multiple times a day. I would be leaning against the counter, absolutely exhausted, and suddenly, out of the corner of my eye, I would spot a horrifying shadow man, curled up in a ball at my feet and staring up at me.
I can't express how terrifying that was. His closeness. His silence. His staring.
I would jolt away in panic before realising that it was just the fucking trash bag... again.
Shit - I would turn the corner and prepare myself for the black mass, and my heart would still do a little somersault when I saw it, because by this point, my brain was automatically afraid whenever I saw it.

I also had sleep paralysis most nights. Still, NONE of this was the worst bit.

1/2

>The bus is full of noisy people
>Normally I dislike crowded buses but today, I'm glad for the crowd. I'm nodding off people-watching is a good way to keep myself conscious.
>I people-watch for a few minutes.
>Then a man gets on the bus, and I forget about everything else.
>I am utterly captivated by him
>The man sits right at the front of the bus, in that weird alcove where two sets of seats are facing each other (two seats facing forwards, and two seats facing backwards).
>He sits in one of the forward-facing seats, with his back to me, and I am utterly entranced by his hair
>It's so beautiful.
>Glossy
>Matte
>Long
>Short
>Wavy
>Straight
Wait, what?
>I realise that my brain is kind of slipping, and I decide to focus on something else to regain my focus
>I look down at the man's neck and shoulders instead
>And I am fucking terrified
>Because his body is facing me, but his head is facing away from me.
HIS HEAD IS ON BACKWARDS
>And somehow I know, in the pit of my stomach, that this entire time that I was watching him, he was somehow watching ME.
>I jolt violently with fright
>The man is gone
>The bus is empty
>All is silent
>The sun is shining and I shiver.
>My hands are shaking and when I get off at my stop 2 minutes later, I tear up from fright, and keep looking behind me, in case the man with the black hair and backwards head is creeping up behind me.
>That night, I go straight to bed and sleep for 40 hours straight. When I wake up, I sleep some more.

I dunno, it's such a lame story, but I still feel sick thinking about that man.

There's a damn good reason sleep deprivation is considered 'torture'. It really is.

>>33871189
Crazy stuff, anon. The interesting thing is that you didn't just see a trope. Most people would see a body facing forward with head backwards, staring at me, spooOOooOOky, for horror story appeal. You saw something novel and weird and that makes it kinda believable. You think it was just a hallucination?

I've got a sleep disorder and pushed my self similarly for a job. 1-3 hours a night for weeks in a row, with some full nights interspersed. Toward the end, I fortunately didn't get to your stage of visual hallucinations, but I did see lights flashing in the periphery and I heard vague voices shouting with an echo. That was when I quit my job and slept for two weeks and got a diagnosis.

I'm thinking of that sleep experiment creepy pasta; one of the results of the experiment was that sleep deprivation puts a person into the control of a different part of the brain that is usually controlled, perhaps by sleeping. Maybe the weird stuff that we perceive isn't just hallucinations, but perception of some other things that our brain usually can't notice or filters.

i got lost on a back desert road in the middle of the arizona desert at about 11pm on a road trip with an ex girlfriend. no phone service, but still had the maps route pre loaded on my phone. it was narrow thin dark oil road. first hunch was native american reservation (i later did some research on the area and found i in fact was on 'sacred ground' for whatever thats worth.

its a long story and ive considered green texting it since someone wrote about skinwalkers taking the shape of orbs of light (some old story i read a while back that i perceive as true as it was anti climactic AND i experienced the same thing)

to sum it up - lost on back road because of apple maps. long road for about an hour. then turned into a smaller more narrow road.. i then passed through a large gate, but a fuckced up gate. like it was made out of petrified wood and had animal bones tied around it and a strip of barbwire across the top. the fence posts marking the gate were at least 9 ft high. as the road got rockier i got more scared but kept my cool. internally. i had never been more scared in my life and was certain i was going to die. my girlfriend was 18 and i was 24 so do the math. i saw a lot of wildlife up until i turned onto this second road then there was nothing. while the road got rockier and more barren (if you were in a 2020 rubicon jeep you would be concerned and i was in a fuckin hatchback sport 90's shit dual sport grandma car) i stopped and told my girlfriend i HAD to check the tires to make sure they were good and she started freaking out.

as i got out of the car. it was silent. and i mean, that greentext story type of silent. not a peep. nothing. silence so loud i wouldve preferred a nuclear bomb. in the distance i saw 2 headlights coming right towards me and got very scared. i was more worried about seeing another person out here instead of a monster. as the lights neared about 50 yards or so they split off into 2. as if it was 2 motorcycles. - 1/2

2/2

here i was even more terrified and was ready to see anything. i then pulled in front of a ranch gate. it was tied shut with barb wire. i exited the car to undo the gate. it was shockingly silent again. then out of nowhere on the other side of the gate. a semi truck plowed past. about 10 yards past the gate on an embankment. there was the highway.

it was JUST like one of those movies where the main character isnt paying attention and the bus zooms by? it was terrifying.

there was some very strange circumstances that led to this detour i was on that included a cop pulling me over prior and making sure i had got a full tank of gas prior to continuing my trip.

i keep the story relatively private to people because it isnt too climactic. but its like, dude if youre in that situation. when youre out there where you dont belong. you dont need to see anything to know youre close to evil. but yea, only time in my life i was certain i was going to die. my ex girlfriend and i are still friends but have never talked bout it lol

This was all in my head so not as scary as some of the stories here, but the scariest experience I had was caused by sleep deprivation. For 2 nights I couldn't fall asleep, and on the 3rd still found myself struggling to sleep.
Trying to relax myself I put on this t.v show, but stupidly chose to put on a horror t.v show. Which only added to a growing sense of unease.
The show was about this woman whose sister went missing when she was a kid and as an adult decides to investigate. She learns her sister (which is also herself kind of) was sacrificed by this pagan cult , yet it gets confusing and the time sequence starts to blur, and her mother is actually like a witch that is continuously in a never-ending cycle sacrificing her child to bring on Spring-time.
Real disturbing stuff.
Anyways I drift into this strange paranoid half-sleep where the sense of paranoia & elements from the movie seem to drift into my half-asleep awareness.
I'm upstairs in my bed, but then suddenly a second passes I open my eyes and I'm back down in my basement couch "How did I get down here or did I dream of going upstairs and it never really happened? Or am I dreaming now?" This seems to repeat several times as though I were trapped in a loop like in the t.v show..
Start questioning my perception. Is anything real how can I tell? Get back into bed for what feels like the thousandth time, but am struck by this crippling fear . I need to go to sleep I know, but somehow feel that it won't be safe.
I sit up hyper-aware, listening, listening, that uncanny sensation that if I listen hard enough I'll hear something listening back. Watching as the hours creep by & I see the light of morning flicker through my window binds and birds chirping.
-------------
Other minor scary incident:
>suddenly wake up, early morning
>feel an overwhelming sense of dread
>look to my right
>inky black writing on the wall
>the words wash away into the air

posts.com:
>Can anyone project/shift/have an out of body experience?
Yes.

>Is it not just a vivid lucid dream?
No. A full successful astral projection/shift/oobe feels just as, and often even more real than the waking reality you're experiencing right now. The difference between this and even extremely vivid lucid dreams is absolutely huge.

>Does it have to be difficult and take me months/years to attain this ability?
No, it does not, the only barrier is your mind - both conscious and subconscious. If you think it's going to be difficult, it will. Many people can be successful within their first few tries.

>How come? And how is even this connected to astral travel?
There exists an infinite amount of realities with infinite "you's" into which you can focus your conscious awareness. Astral projection and other OOBEs are, in essence, the same thing - projecting your consciousness into the Astral Plane etc.

>Do I have to come back?
Not from shifting.
Yes from projecting, but also somewhat up for debate.

>Does this have anything to do with the teenager trend spreading on TikTok and in other places?
Yes and no. Kids latching onto an idea they may not even understand, pay them no attention.

>any advice on breaking through the stage im stuck on
Most powerful technique is to manipulate your subconscious mind through denial of desires. For example, make it a point that you'll eat no more food until you astral project, once you finally AP you can eat again. You could also do this with sexual gratification, internet, water, anything that has powerful urges connected to it, you deny that desire and tell yourself the only way to get what you want is to astral project. The point is creating as much stress as possible within the subconscious, resulting in powerful subconscious motivation to AP, which is especially important because it's highly probable that right now you're subconsciously resistant to AP.

What techniques you use in combination with this isn't super important, it's only important that you practice them as often as possible. What's most likely going to happen is you're going to fall asleep at some point during this process and your subconscious will do the work for you, you'll wake up right into the mind awake body asleep/vibratory stage and that's when the work you've put towards practicing separation will be most useful

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33820441
Body asleep, mind awake.

Lay down, almost like you're about to fall asleep. Get into to a comfortable position. Next, close your eyes and keep your mind awake while your body drifts asleep.

The key part about keeping your mind awake is this: it doesn't mean staying alert. Body asleep. Mind awake. Sit back, and relax. Don't think too hard, let thoughts come to you. You will be laying down on your bed, and the thoughts will come to you bubbling into your mind. Let them grow. Look at them, focus on them. Eventually, images, and sounds will form. Peer into those. Walk into it, as if you were walking with your body.

And there you have it!

The idea that physics says you can't have perpetual motion is actually a misconception based off of statistical arguments about entropy.

What's funny is that the beginning of those arguments starts with something that's literally called "the fundamental assumption of thermodynamics" and that idea literally says entropy can reverse and perpetual motion IS possible.
They actually START from a law that says it's possible. The reason they later claim that it's not possible is because in the statistical limit of large every-day systems (and assuming a smooth distribution of the material) the probability goes toward 0.

The fact that so many physicists take such a weak argument to be a irrevocable law is, in my opinion, the single biggest indicator that they aren't immune to dogma.

And by the way, you don't have to take my word for it. Physicists have already started experimentally observing entropy reversal (which means they've experimentally verified that perpetual motion is possible).
Because these days it's not uncommon to work in nano-systems which are well below that statistical limit I mentioned (small number of particles).
But they dodn't call it for what it is, they have to call it "time reversal" to avoid the dogma... And the funniest joke of all is that if you can reverse time then you fucking well can have entropy reversal too, and perpetual motion, so they're still permitting it anyway! lol

posts.com:
CBR Proves Earth's Motion Through Space

The ability to measure the cosmic background radiation (CBR) gives us something the physicists of the early/mid 20th century could only dream of: a universal frame of reference by which to establish if Earth is really moving linearly or if it just appears to be. The CBR permeates all of space. If an object is at rest relative to the CBR then the frequencies observed will be the same in all directions. If an object is moving relative to the CBR, then Doppler shift will reveal in what direction and how fast.

We measured this phenomenon and established Earth's linear motion through space using the COBE satellite in operation from 1989 to 1993. What did we find? That the Earth is definitely moving through the cosmos.

https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/how-fast-is-the-earth-mov/

>In 1989, the COBE satellite was placed in orbit about the earth (again, the earth is the frame of reference!) to measure the long-diluted radiation echo of the birth of our universe. This radiation, which remains from the immensely hot and dense primordial fireball that was our early universe, is known as the cosmic microwave background radiation (CBR). The CBR presently pervades all of space. It is the equivalent of the entire universe "glowing with heat."
>One of COBE's discoveries was that the earth was moving with respect to this CBR with a well-defined speed and direction. Because the CBR permeates all space, we can finally answer the original question fully, using the CBR as the frame of reference.
>The earth is moving with respect to the CBR at a speed of 390 kilometers per second. We can also specify the direction relative to the CBR. It is more fun, though, to look up into the night sky and find the constellation known as Leo (the Lion). The earth is moving toward Leo at the dizzying speed of 390 kilometers per second.

FLERFERS LIE

Take a close look at the attached pic. Flerfers often post it as proof the Earth is flat. Why do I want you to look at it? Because it's a lie.

"The Australian Black Swan" tells you that the maximum line of sight for a 5.5ft tall observer is 2.35 miles. But the cliff is 7.8 miles away. So what's wrong with this flat Earth "proof"? *** Line of sight depends on both observer and target height, as well as on atmospheric refraction. *** The lighthouse is at least 100ft tall which means the visible cliff is at least 400ft tall. LoS for a 5.5ft observer of a 500ft (combined height) target is 35 miles.

What about the oil platforms? Ocean oil platforms have an "air gap" between the ocean and the first deck of 40-60 feet. Observer height was listed as 1ft (camera on the ground?). With a 40ft first deck the line of sight is 10 miles. With a 60ft first deck it's 12 miles. With a 5ft observer and a 60ft first deck it would be 14 miles.

At 6.21 and 9.41 miles you would still see the entire structure above the first deck even if the first deck was only 40ft off the ocean and the camera really was on the ground at 1ft. For the closer platform you would see some structure below the first deck. Note that we see more of the closer rig, proving curvature.

Here's a line of sight calculator: http://www.calculatoredge.com/electronics/lineofsight.htm

>but we're talkin' about muh horizon
>MUH HORIZON IS TOO FAR AWAY!
No it's not. It's between the observer and target in both photos. That's why the observer cannot see the very bottom of the target.

posts.com:
DAILY REMINDER - GPS absolutely proves globe Earth, rotating Earth, space, orbiting satellites, time dilation (relativity), and gravity.

Flerfers will point to LORAN and claim that GPS could work off of transmitters sitting on the ground, on balloons, or on airplanes. But it cannot.

Why? I'm glad you asked.

In tracking mode GPS receivers use Doppler signal analysis to determine receiver velocity. It is impossible for a transmitter to fake Doppler signal shift to multiple receivers across 360°. If the transmitter was lying about its speed, then the receiver would think that it was moving at high mach based on the incorrect Doppler shift in the signal. And since GPS is computed in 3D space from four satellite signals, if the satellites were lying about their positions (altitudes) the resulting location and altitude on the receiver would be off by thousands of miles.

This means that GPS satellites are provably at orbital altitudes and speeds, because GPS could not function at all if the satellites were lying. And if the satellites aren't lying, then space is real. Orbits are real. But the dome is not real. Not unless the satellites punched through it.

What about Earth's shape? GPS receivers use a spherical model of Earth. If Earth was really flat, then receivers would report altitudes literally thousands of miles off. This means Earth really is a sphere.

Furthermore, both Earth's rotation and time dilation must be accounted for in GPS. If either one was not true then, once again, receivers would give obviously false and useless results. That means Earth really is rotating. And time dilation is real. And if both orbits and time dilation are real, that pretty much guarantees that gravity is real.

No single instrument completely shatters all of flat Earth mythology quite like the GPS constellation. It really is a beautiful thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Box That Killed The Dome

If you remove the lid of a pressurized box of air inside of a vacuum chamber without gravity, the air will violently rush out of the box to fill the vacuum. The air pressure will then be the same at every point in the chamber. It will be the same at the top, bottom, middle, and at all sides. Just like the air pressure in your car tires or a balloon or a SCUBA tank.

This thought experiment debunks the entire flat Earth model. If the air does not cling to the bottom of the chamber, then it certainly would not cling to the bottom of flat Earth. If the air does not leave any part of the chamber still in vacuum, then it certainly would not leave any part of flat Earth in vacuum. And if the air creates equal pressure at all points in the chamber, then certainly the air creates equal pressure at all points in the flat Earth dome.

Yet there is no denying that air thins as you climb in altitude. At 100,000 feet, somewhere near the top of the theorized dome, the air pressure is so low that it is effectively a vacuum.

This alone debunks all of flat Earth.

Note: no flerfer has ever provided a workable answer to this. They immediately sperg out if you even mention it, and rant and rave that the box thought experiment actually kills the globe. The only way they can do this, of course, is to deny gravity. But if gravity doesn't exist then the dome is just as dead. And if it does exist, the globe model works, while the dome remains...dead.

"In fact, this paper by the U.S. Naval Observatory tells us that, while incorporating Einstein’s equations into the system may slightly improve accuracy, the system itself doesn’t rely on them at all.

At high altitude, where the GPS clocks orbit the Earth, it is known that the clocks run roughly 46,000 nanoseconds (one-billionth of a second) a day faster than at ground level, because the gravitational field is thinner 20,000 kilometers above the Earth. The orbiting clocks also pass through that field at a rate of three kilometers per second — their orbital speed. For that reason, they tick 7,000 nanoseconds a day slower than stationary clocks.

To offset these two effects, the GPS engineers reset the clock rates, slowing them down before launch by 39,000 nanoseconds a day. They then proceed to tick in orbit at the same rate as ground clocks, and the system “works.” Ground observers can indeed pin-point their position to a high degree of precision. In (Einstein) theory, however, it was expected that because the orbiting clocks all move rapidly and with varying speeds relative to any ground observer (who may be anywhere on the Earth’s surface), and since in Einstein’s theory the relevant speed is always speed relative to the observer, it was expected that continuously varying relativistic corrections would have to be made to clock rates. This in turn would have introduced an unworkable complexity into the GPS. But these corrections were not made. Yet “the system manages to work, even though they use no relativistic corrections after launch,” Van Flandern said. “They have basically blown off Einstein”.
https://medium.com/@GatotSoedarto/top-4-reasons-why-gps-doesnt-need-einstein-s-relativity-895cabc6e619

LMFAO! I've encountered that midwit.com article before.

First: the very section you quoted affirms time dilation due to gravity and speed. And affirms that corrections are required for GPS to work. It's just pulling a sleight of hand by setting up a false conflict between "muh simple corrections" and "muh complex Einstein corrections!" There is no conflict. The author is just stupid.

Second: the referenced paper does not deny that relativity applies to GPS. It explicitly confirms it. The paper discusses the corrections made at all points in the system so that receivers on Earth generally do not have to apply more complex equations to the problem. But the paper was written to address situations where receivers MUST APPLY the complex corrections for the required accuracy. The midwit.com author is claiming that the paper proves Einstein's relativity is irrelevant to GPS because "muh simple corrections", when in fact the paper is saying "don't think you can ignore Einstein's equations with GPS, because GPS fails in x,y,z situations without them."

Third: as part of the author's sleight of hand, he included a dead link to the original paper. He did this hoping nobody with a higher IQ than him (which is a lot of people) would skim the paper and notice all of his errors.

Intrusion in Dreams

Gopal Krishna Yachendra described the following incident to Haraldsson. He was a son of the raja of Venkatagiri, who had got to know Sai Baba early his career and wished to invite him to his palace. He ordered his son to fetch him, but Gopal refused, saying he had no interest in gurus or swamis. That night he woke from a dream shortly after falling asleep. Sai Baba had come to him and brought him a delicious mango, which he loved. The dream changed everything: Gopal quickly got dressed and set out with his attendants, arriving at Puttaparthi at lunchtime the following day. As they approached they saw Sai Baba standing on the other side of the river, and before they could speak, Sai Baba said: ‘The mango made you run here’. That convinced Gopal that Sai Baba’s talents were real.

Bilocation

Sai Baba was said to have disappeared and reappeared in a place so distant that he could not have done so by ordinary means or, sometimes, was seen in two places at the same time (bilocation). Osis and Haraldsson investigated a case that occurred in Kerala on the south west coast of India, interviewing those involved. Sai Baba visited a house of a family where a young girl was ill, suddenly appearing in the doorway. He initiated a sacred ceremony in which religious hymns were sung; family members and neighbours all taking part. It was assumed that Sai Baba had been visiting Kerala, and had taken the opportunity to stop by the family’s house. But afterwards it was discovered this was not the case: at this time he had been visiting in the palace of the raja of Venkatagiri on the east coast of India. Osis observed Sai Baba’s signature in the guestbook of the Venkatagiri family on the day he appeared in Kerala.

Hi /x/

Some anons may recall some spiritual conflict: much of these events are fragmented, distorted and twisted into an amalgamation of (dis-)information that may be difficult to deal with. To some degree its events may have affected you or people you know in ways they don't even understand. In the last week I've mostly caught onto vibes from dragon beings in meditations; a deep foreboding grief that wordlessly told of an unspeakable amount of suffering inflicted by them upon others and of others upon them. It promptly adjusted my view of them. I can see the past being the past, but it is sobering and not entirely surprising if one contemplates the nature of conflict. As above so below.

In any case, I've been helped by other anons, please consider setting your antennas in meditation to your feelings and relations with these beings. And as with all conflicts: folks form their groups and alliances and when digging deep enough I think everyone here on Earth can find their roots in it: for dark and light. This requires time, reflection and timing. Sometimes a particular thread or word can already trigger something in you: catch it and hold it.
1. Some folk on Earth or beyond have been subject to ethereal assault. They tend to struggle with spiritual connections, healthy astral projection and/or sense of self or past recall. No processing without awareness.
2. Your experience and recall are non-linear. You can increase linearity of events by sharing what you know and reaching consensus with your fellow souls. Inconsistent or incomplete information may be eliminated over time.
3. The dragon's impulse to settle the grief was immensely strong and felt like a focus point. Personal grief cannot flow without understanding and confrontation. There might be things you don't want to remember, especially ethereal abuse, but without going through it it'll just stay a blockage. Dwell on them, your own resonance: find feelings, emotions or fears that feel out of place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33882627
4. A key-word in the clusterfuck was escalation and growing ever more merciless. But from what I've felt, all sides have done things they have regretted. What's important is that whoever has been affected by these matters is able to put into words for themselves what the consequences are to self and others. I've met a sister in the higher planes who quarelled with me until we settled our differences. I've met a dragon who's mother I had killed. I met a dragon being that enslaved and abused folk by inducing smth like stockholm syndrome. I've met dragons who I protected and loved dearly. I've had to endure wrathful Alfar and worked with them to get their brothers and sisters safe. The things you love might just be conditioned, while your true roots lie elsewhere.
5. Your perspective is more limited here, so don't be quick. Some things do not deserve forgiveness or acceptance from the get go. It's a process that you need to give time. But don't cheat and take the easy road. Trust your gut, use your brain and listen at heart for the right emotion to come loose: that's when you've resolved it.
6. Some spirits want to be heard, others want to rage, others want understanding. It takes time and listening. Most that come to you will show that in their own way.
7. There is no such thing as innocence. Each soul involved has their blemishes; you won't know yours until it's time. You also don't know if some actions were made with full lucidity, freedom or indoctrination. Take ownership, but be real. If you feel you were wronged or attacked: don't be sorry for it. Do be open to radiate the grief that it happened at all. The Alfar taught me more with that gesture.

tl;dr got pinged heavily by dragon collective and figured to put it out there so other people might catch onto the signal to meditate upon and find whatever they may need to dig, heal, vent or know. Mind it, invite it in, be curious, who knows what might come.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOoqThp3qUM

posts.com:
not him but, there's so many things that can go awry. Even among dragonkind themselves things have not always been rosy, and stoic authority will inevitably meet forms of rebellion. Some of those were fought tooth and nail: others more gently or manipulative.
And when they intersect the consciousness of other beings it spawns another host of trouble. I've felt vibes of disdain for dragons lowering themselves to work with people. I've felt the opposite too, along the lines of: "If we're happy this way mind your own business."

They retreated themselves from one time and place because of horrific acts: enslavement, degradation (of culture and sense of self), experimentation. I've had a particular vivid vision of having to put down a dragon companion who was suffering from a disease. The connotation being it was not a natural one and widespread. Eventually, who's there to say a physical being may not be put to good use and over time, it's sense of pride and self replaced with something that is a sad sight for their brothers and sisters beyond?
Dragons value their freedom; when take or corrupted they take it unkindly. I can imagine easily that a consolidation of power would clash with dragon ideals. Imagine their minds around in a senate.

There was a lot of warmth too. There's something about crossing a hill with a few dragons peacefully snoozing in the sun or visiting some remote mountain dwellers after a long hike. I remain mixed for some reason. I know there to be things under the waves of the unconscious that would make me drop their hearts like a brick, not meaning one should, but like a portent of things to come. If it truly is the greatest force: where is love born and where does it die?

>>33886627
That's horary and electional astrology. It is done via a transit chart over your natal chart, or a chart by itself for a specific date.

The planets affect your psychology at all times but in different ways throughout time. What such horoscopes can show you is where your mind and energy will be at that moment in time.

If you wished to know when to confess your love to someone, you'd try to find a day where you'd have ample courage and self-confidence, and your love interest would be feeling most receptive to romantic advances.

But yes, astrology can do this, and it seems you hadn't realized that this is what colloquial horoscopes have been purporting to do all along. Those pop astrologers choose a degree for a natal sun, and then look at the placements (which may or may not aspect that sun) for the date the horoscopes are cast. They speculate about how each sun sign will deal with the particular placements of the day/week/month/year and then extrapolate to give readers a generalized reading supposedly applicable to all of them.

posts.com:
>>33885776
>but I continually find myself creating and fighting thoughtforms without intending to
That's because you're falling for the trap. If you try to not think of a giraffe the act of trying to not think about one means you're thinking about one.
How can your mind know what to filter out unless it already holds the thing it's trying to filter?

I'm not saying that this is something you have to overcome, I'm saying that whoever/whatever led you to believe this is the way to do things was probably intentionally trying to lead you into this mind trap where you'll constantly be fighting your own thoughts.
But thought policing is an unhealthy waste of time because your thoughts don't actually matter at all.

Think about this - How is it possible that you can fight your own thoughts unless there is _already_ some part of you that is separate from those thoughts and realizes that it doesn't identify with those thoughts?
When you see that then try to realize that part of you is where the real power lies, not in the thoughts.
Don't fight the thoughts, instead just become more aware of the part of you that already knows which thoughts you do or don't identify with, and don't empower the thought by feeling like you have to come up with a counter-thought. Just let it go.

In the dream, I had just woken up in my bedroom and was preparin to get out of bed when an incredibly loud voice said "It is time." and it sounded like they were right besides me. The voice sounded masculine, but very old and tired.

I should also say that I live in a basement, and my bedroom only has a single tiny window to the outside. In the dream, after the voice spoke, there was an incredibly loud boom, which after a little bit of research I think was one of the trumpets mentioned in the book of revelations, though in the dream it was so loud I couldn't really understand the sound.

Then, as I was burning alive, I heard someone calling my name several times. I looked at the source of the sound and there was a massive golden throne floating in the fire, with a bright light occupying it. After seeing that, I heard my name one more time and then I woke up.

>>33884382
An awful lot of them should, yeah. Would stuff like Saw or August Underground be allowed in any remotely healthy society? A lot of horror panders to sadists and engenders sadism in people who aren't sadists already. And a good portion of what's left over glamorizes black magic. I used to be extremely into horror and that's a community that's full of legit creeps and occultists too.

"It's just art, calm down!" is the same as "I'm being ironic". What someone finds artistically worthwhile and funny tells us a lot about them and art and humor are often used to obscure actual beliefs and interests. If some kid is constantly "ironically" talking about school shootings, it's not unreasonable to be worried.

And there's also this weird switchup that happens whenever broad swathes of art are condemned. Normally art is supposed to be this extremely valuable thing, basically synonymous with culture, the artist is a shamanic hero and art is a path to transcendence and heroic self-expression. But when you point out that a ton of it is so degenerate it ought to be banned, suddenly art becomes no big deal and the people reacting to it are being crazy by taking it seriously. It's very slimy.

If you look at premodern religious and philosophical writings, they're full of commands and recommendations to be careful what you view and to not enjoy killing in battle more than you should. That goes for very much non-pacifist religions like Islam and very much non-pacifist cultures like Athens.

I'm not arguing that we should shelter people, if anything the opposite, I don't view (just and decently conducted) war as a bad thing and I think the harsher living conditions and working environments of those times forced people to confront mortality and think about the purpose of this life and what comes after it. We're so comfortable that we can afford to run away from it until we can't. But that doesn't mean that wallowing in and salivating over violence is a good thing, there's a lot of middle ground.

1) The situation needs to be physically inescapable, no one with a brain will believe you stay in mortal danger for years because "muh wife", "muh kids" and "muh money problems.

i encountered a sasquatch last year in the northern cascades while hiking alone.
i took a video of it.
then after that i was overcome with dread so i ran and somehow got lost 3 miles up this mountain for over an hour, slipping and sliding down this steep grade, holding on to branches and bushes.
And while i was lost there was about a dozen tree knocks in total, following me from the left and right.
anyways, i sat down finally and asked in my mind “sasquatch, can you help me find the trail? i’m lost and just want to go to back to camp”
i had nothing to lose, i just thought that and sent it away and kept walking.

so as i’m heading down, holding on to branches because of the steepness of the slope, and i hear this massive ROAR from over my right shoulder.
it reverberated my entire chest and body and was so terrifying, i instinctively turned left to get away from the noise.
i was too scared to even look back, it sounded like a fucking lion, and i’m heading left now instead of down.
about 100 yards later i reach a small cliff and find the trail.

As i’m walking down the trail, i’m looking over to the right where i was lost, and the mountain gave way to huge steep gravely and loose shale cliffs. if i had continued even another 100 yards, i would’ve easily slipped and fallen to my death or serious injury.

so whatever made that roar that forced me to turn left at that exact moment saved my life.

I feel incredibly humbled and lucky to have had this experience. i got a video of it, it showed itself to me, because right before the encounter i was singing songs about sasquatch and how i want to see one.
These things are real, and they are more than animals.

I was there in Hong Kong throughout the entire event, but I had no direct or indirect interaction with anyone involved in the protests because I was under official cover at the US consulate in HK.

I did however design a large part of the training and indoctrination techniques that were taught and used on the protestors. My biggest contribution was a position I created called "Revolution Consultants" and "People Leaders" which were part of these pro-democracy organizations, and I designed a fake history for these non-profit orgs which involved them helping inspire and set up revolutions to change oppressive government policies worldwide. It was all made to sound really pretentious and appealing to the outspoken "activist" mindset that a lot of these young people had. They were mostly college students.

These so-called revolutionary consultants were at first officers who were under Non-official cover with identities that had no ties to the US government. We communicated with them indirectly and face-to-face briefings would take place outside HK and the mainland in places like Thailand or the Philippines. The officers would then recruit candidates (usually members of student orgs at universities or members of trade unions) to fill out new "consultant" positions, and these guys would find people under them to do the same. In design, it was pretty much very similar to a Multi-Level marketing shill, but designed for "revolutionary activities," It also helped further distance our people further and further from the actual protestors, and the presence of so-many "consultants" and "leaders" with equal ranking helped to decentralize the chain-of-command, which was to prevent everything from going to shit if a large number of them were arrested.

Serious answer, I think you ARE your reality. You're not in it, you are it.
You are all that you consciously experience. You're the color coming off your screen as you read this. You're the sound in the room.
All of those things are what's real and they form a bubble around an empty center that we've been taught is who we are. Your ego "I" is like a focal point of nothingness.

Think about it, at the center where your "I" exists there is no experience. But we focus on that point anyway.
It's like a cage that keeps you focused on an unreal illusion so you don't focus on the real. What's real is around it, the pure consciousness that makes you think you're an "I" in the first place.

So in truth there's nothing to "escape" because you aren't "in" a reality, you don't go anywhere. Escape means to change your reality into what you want it to be instead of what it's told to be by the illusion of the "world".
But again, I don't believe the experience would be like going somewhere. It would be more like everything just transforming.
It can happen slow, or it can take a long time. And I think the fact that you want it to happen means that it's already happening, just slowly.

The quality of the photos is the biggest giveaway for multiple reasons.
The film was not stored with any kid of lead protection at all. Passing through the van Allen radiation belt would have "exposed" the film rendering it useless.

The photos are taken with perfect clarity. These are manually focused cameras with viewfinder and the photographers were supposedly holding the cameras at chest height. They took all these perfect photos without using the viewfinder and by manually focusing with those heavy gloves.

In addition, the foreground and background are both in focus.

As for the video, it's slowed down 1/3rd speed. Would we move faster or slower if we went to a moon with more gravity? Their equipment weight wouldn't be a factor because the moons gravity was supposed to be less than 1/7th that of earth. Which means for them to walk at normal speed, their gear would have to weigh 6 times their own weight, but it was in fact less. But let's be generous and say the astronaut weighed 175 pounds and his gear was another 175 pounds on earth. In total, on the moon he would weigh 58.1 pounds, and should be able to do cartwheels with ease

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33875342
>The quality of the photos is the biggest giveaway for multiple reasons.
>The film was not stored with any kid of lead protection at all. Passing through the van Allen radiation belt would have "exposed" the film rendering it useless.
You have either never researched this and are ignorant, or you are a liar. The total radiation exposure from a mission was equivalent to a few years of background radiation on Earth. Does film go bad in a few years? Nope. You can shoot film 20 years old easily, and if you're willing to compensate for the aging in development, you won't even notice the difference. NASA developed test strips off each roll and adjusted development. You would be hard pressed to find the light fogging from radiation WITHOUT them doing this.

>The photos are taken with perfect clarity. These are manually focused cameras with viewfinder and the photographers were supposedly holding the cameras at chest height. They took all these perfect photos without using the viewfinder and by manually focusing with those heavy gloves.
Again, you have either never researched this, or you are a liar.
https://www.flickr.com/photos/projectapolloarchive/

>In addition, the foreground and background are both in focus.
So now we have three things you are ignorant about. They were shooting in the equivalent of full daylight on Earth, and with no atmospheric attenuation of the sunlight. Lookup "sunny 16" and tell us what you think happens when you stop a lens down to f/16.

>Would we move faster or slower if we went to a moon with more gravity?
Assuming you meant to say "less gravity." But you would not be racing around because you are in a bulky spacesuit and you are also very much aware that a mistake could be dangerous.

To the faggot anon in the thread have a look into this https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Baron

Baron's report
Baron compiled a 169-page report critical of safety standards at North American Aviation, and leaked his report to the media.[4] After NAA learned of this, they fired him.

After the Apollo 1 fire, Baron wrote a 275-page report on NASA safety protocol violations, which he gave to Rep. Olin E. Teague's investigation at Cape Kennedy, Florida, on April 21, 1967.[5]

The chairman of the NASA Oversight Committee claimed that Baron had made a valuable contribution to the Apollo fire probe, but that he had been "overzealous".[6]

Death
Six days after his testimony, Baron was killed instantly, along with his wife and stepdaughter, when a train crashed into their car near their home in Florida.[1][7]

It removes the color filter, restores uncensored camera angles for interrogation kills (sometimes glitchy), enables exploding headshots, and most importantly, reinstates interrogation points, meaning when you kill someone through an interrogation, you actually earn points instead of losing them, the way the game was originally meant to be.
